title: Fined Jets OL Kelechi Osemele will have surgery even if team doesn't authorize it
text:
CLOSE Sports Pulse: The Bears continue to fall, as the quarterbacks on the Packers, Vikings and Colts shine. USA TODAY

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Kelechi Osemele says he’s getting surgery, whether the Jets authorize it or not. It’s just the latest development in a complicated injury dispute between the offensive lineman and the Jets.

Osemele said he got a third opinion on the shoulder Tuesday in Boston, and that the doctor recommended immediate surgery on his torn labrum.

“He informed me that it’s pretty bad,” Osemele said. "It’s torn off the bone and he needs to operate. So that’s what I’m going to do.”

He’s scheduled an operation for Friday.

Osemele hasn’t played or practiced since Week 3 and requested the Jets authorize surgery on the shoulder weeks ago.

The Jets denied the request and since last week they’ve been fining him for conduct detrimental to the team because he’s missing practice. A source said the Jets believe Osemele is healthy enough to play through the injury and delay surgery until after the season.

The Jets did not comment on Osemele’s decision to have surgery. Osemele said he still hasn’t heard back from the team since he informed them of his decision to undergo surgery.

“We sent them the full doctor’s report this morning, so we don’t know yet,” Osemele said. “They have been cooperative, they have sent worker’s compensation forms needed to get the surgery. So it is moving forward.

“I think they’re doing the best to do the right thing. So now that they’ve done that it’s really their decision whether or not they choose to authorize it or not, but I’ve got to take care of my body, I’ve got to take care of my health, I’ve got a family, so I’ve got to take care of myself.”

NFL TRADE DEADLINE: Seven deals that teams should make in 2019

COUNTDOWN IS OVER: Here are the top 100 players to ever play in the NFL

Kelechi Osemele of the New York Jets (Photo: AP)

Osemele confirmed that the Jets have been fining him the maximum amount under the NFL’s collective bargaining agreement: his entire game check, in excess of $579,000 per week. But Osemele said he’s filed a grievance against the Jets through the NFLPA, and that he’s confident he’ll get his money back.

“Legally, when a player can’t go and he’s in pain and he has multiple doctor’s opinions that say he needs surgery, a team can’t just be like, ‘You can’t have surgery.’” Osemele said. “You can’t do that. It’s just ethically and morally wrong.”

If the Jets don’t authorize the surgery, Osemele would have to pay for it himself. Osemele’s agents issued a statement to ESPN on Wednesday, saying that the Jets’ insurance provider has approved the surgery and that if the team doesn’t give the green light, “he will have all of his rights under the CBA enforced through the legal process.”

Osemele initially had two opinions on his injured shoulder, one from the Jets team doctor and another from an independent doctor. Osemele confirmed that the Jets sent a blank MRI to the independent doctor and then sent the wrong MRI, before finally getting the correct images there.

“(GM Joe) Douglas Tod me that was a mistake … it wasn’t intentional or anything like that,” Osemele said. “It was just an honest mistake trying to send the MRI, is what I was told.”

Osemele was adamant he needed surgery after the first two opinions. But got he got a third opinion earlier this week because he wanted to give the team a “more definitive opinion” and be examined by a doctor in person.

The Jets wanted Osemele to keep playing because they believed his injury was a pre-existing condition and he’d been playing through it all season, according to a source.

Osemele said he first had pain in the shoulder Aug. 5, during training camp. He said he’d been getting treatment on the shoulder ever since, even though he never showed up on the Jets’ injury report. He also said he’s been taking injections of the pain killer Toradol to play through the pain, but that the injections stopped working and he couldn’t continue.

“You’re at a point where it’s like, ‘Now what do I do? ‘Do I take Vicodin?’” Osemele said. “Like, where is the line? How much should a player play through pain? Where is the limit? Is there a limit? Like, am I just supposed to be in pain and miserable every day? Does my health not matter?”

There’s suspicion within the organization that Osemele only decided to have the surgery once he lost his starting job to Alex Lewis. Osemele flatly denied that.

“Absolutely not,” he said. “The decision was made before that (lineup decision) even happened, like during the bye week the decision was made. So that had nothing to do with it. And Alex is my best friend on the team. Like, we’re boys. So it definitely has nothing to do with that.”

Osemele admitted it’s been “awkward” coming to the facility every day while he’s engaged in a dispute with the team. He compared it to “walking into a home where you’re not supposed to be there and they don’t really want you there.”

But he said his teammates have been supportive of him throughout this strange situation.

“[They’re] saying like, ‘It’s (expletive), sorry for what you’re going through, I can’t believe this is happening.’ (Expletive) like that,” Osemele said.

As for his future with the Jets, Osemele is certain there isn’t one. Considering the injury-dispute animosity and Osemele’s massive, $11.7 million in non-guaranteed salary in 2020, Osemele expects to be cut after the season.

“Absolutely,” he said laughing. “100 percent.”

Follow Andy Vasquez on Twitter @andy_vasquez
description: In the latest development in a complicated injury dispute between offensive lineman Kelechi Osemele and the Jets, he will have surgery no matter what.
